Award.AwardTitle: Heterojunction Solar Cells Using Chemically co-doped Titania Nanotube Arrays for Simultaneous Light Absorption and Carrier Transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This project centers on the fundamental understanding of the band gap engineering of nanowires, the band alignment at the nanowire heterojunction, and their effects on carrier injection and transport. The research aims to engineer both the TiO2 band gap by co-doping and the TiO2 surface with a p-type semiconductor heterojunction for solar cells in order to increase absorption, to separate charge separation via control of band alignment, and to minimize surface recombination. The research activities are at the intersection of physics, chemistry, and engineering, involving density functional theory, material synthesis, device fabrication, and structural and physical property characterizations and modeling. An important project goal is to develop a heterojunction solar cell based on chemically co-doped titania nanotube coated with a solution processed p-type semiconductor.
Nontechnical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. Energy sustainability is expected to be the main potential benefit to the society of this research project on solar cells. The material systems and devices developed, as well as the fundamental knowledge gained, can be extended to other areas such as solid state lighting, chemical sensing, and flexible electronics. The project provides interdisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students.

TiO2 is a wide gap semiconductor commonly used for solar energy harvesting applications. A main obstacle for such applications is its large band gap, which absorbs only a small portion of the solar power. Under the project supported by NSF, we conducted systematic and mechanism-informed study on engineering the band gap of TiO2. The concept that we explored is called chemical codoping, as illustrated in Figure 1 (Chemical Codoping), where the codopants (e.g., N and P) both assume the anion sites and form a strong chemical bond. A main advantage of having both dopants on the anion sites is that only the top of the valence band will be modified, while leaving the bottom of conduction band nearly intact. This property is desired for important applications, such as the solar-driven photocatalytic water splitting for generating hydrogen fuels. The advantage of having the strong chemical bonding is that the formation energy of such defects will be significantly reduced, which is a desired property for introducing large concentration of the dopants into the TiO2 lattice.

We developed a sequential doping scheme with nitrogen (N) leading the way, followed by phosphorous (P), which is crucial for the incorporation of both N and P into the anion sites. Previous attempts of P doping in TiO2 only realized at the Ti sites because of the large size-mismatch between P and O. We have confirmed the formation of the N-P bonds using various characterization techniques. As a consequence of the chemical codoping, the band gap of the TiO2 is reduced from 3.2 eV to 1.8 eV. The absorption in the visible range has been significantly improved, as shown in Figure 2 (UV-vis absorption).

In addition to this key success on chemical codoping in TiO2, we have systematically studied a series of semiconductor materials that can form heterojunction with TiO2 for the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, including Cu(In,Ga)Se2 (CIGS), Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS), and CH3NH3PbI3 (MAPbI3) using both experimental and theoretical approaches. In particular, a single source multi-stage technique has been developed for depositing CIGS thin films and possible deep defect levels in CZTS and MAPbI3 that could be detrimental to device performance have been identified. A theoretical method for calculating the alignment of the semiconductor band edge positions with the absolute redox potentials has been proposed under the support of this project.

The outcomes of this project are expected to have important impacts to broader disciplines. The band edge positions in homogeneous materials also determine the ability to ionize dopants and the degree to which spin states inside the band gap can delocalize and interact with each other. This is very important in the magnetism and spin polarization in transition metal doped wide gap semiconductors. Thus, the principle of simultaneous control of the band gap and band alignment of semiconductor oxides is an important step forward in improving the general performance of electronic, optoelectronic, spintronic and magnetic devices.

Once formed, such complex dopants could be kinetically stabilized in the material because the diffusion of a molecule is much more difficult than a single atom. Molecular doping using precursors containing the desired moiety of the complex could be a practical route of introducing such complexes and could be a promising approach for overcoming the thermodynamic doping bottleneck. ...
